Fig. 1 Time dependence of NiCuMo-SiO2 catalyst resistance to corrosion during treatment with 1 M acetic acid water solution. Dashed line-theoretic curve, the result of approximation by the least-square method. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 H2-TPR profile of fresh NiCuMo-SiO2 catalyst. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (M/Si)after HOAc/(M/Si)initial ratio versus time of 1 M HOAc treatment based on XRF data. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Specific surface area ABET and CO uptake of fresh reduced NiCuMo-SiO2 catalyst and 1 M HOAc treated samples. Graphical abstract The main reasons of catalysts deactivation in hydro-processing pyrolysis liquids are by coke deposition, poisoning by bio-oil impurities (S, N, K, Cl, etc.), leaching of catalyst components, structural degradation in the presence of H2O, and sintering. The deactivation of catalysts by the acidity of the pyrolysis liquid is a specific concern, and this deactivation mechanism was studied by treating newly developed NiCuMo-SiO2 catalysts in 1 M acetic acid water solution (pH = 2–3). The activity of the acid-treated catalysts was subsequently investigated in the hydrodeoxygenation of gaseous propionic acid, in a tubular reactor at 225 °C with n-hexane and n-octane serving as diluent and internal standard, respectively. The samples treated by acid at different times (15–360 min) were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), high resolution transition electron microscopy (HRTEM), X-ray fluorescence (XRF), CO chemisorption, N2 physical adsorption, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). XRF and HRTEM studies together with the residual mass of catalyst pointed out at gradual leaching of catalyst components. Among the catalyst components, dissolution of nickel was the most pronounced, while molybdenum content decreased to a lesser extent. This is due to the formation of more acid stable molybdenum blues. The amount of copper decreased only slightly, due its higher electrochemical potential. Oxidation of metalliс species Cu and Ni is shown to obtain Cu2O, NiO and Ni(OH)2-like phases. Interestingly, the acidic treatment resulted in increasing active surface of the catalyst, nevertheless, the catalyst activity in propionic acid conversion irreversibly decreased in time by the acetic acid treatment due to loss of the active components (substantially nickel). Keywords Hydrotreatment Nickel-based catalyst Stability Acetic acid Propionic acid 1 Introduction Use of renewable energy resources attracts much attention as the oil reserves are gradually depleting, and the necessity to lower the carbon footprint becomes obvious due to increased buildup of CO2 in the atmosphere. The use of biomass derived liquids/fuels is promising, as biomass is the only renewable carbon resource with a sufficiently short reproduction cycles and the liquid state allows easy use in existing processes. Among all biomass conversion methods, the thermochemical conversion by fast pyrolysis is considered one of the most promising, being relative simple and cost effective. A detailed discussion on this technology is beyond the scope of the present paper, and the reader is directed to extensive reviewing literature [1–3]. Relevant to mention here is that such pyrolysis liquids still contain a large amount of oxygen (in water, but also as acids), and an upgrading step to reduce/remove these oxygen is deemed required. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) process is one of the most viable options for downstream upgrading of such liquids, eventually to produce liquid transportation fuels [4]. Research and patent literature [5–10] have demonstrated a number of crucial challenges, which must be resolved before this process becomes feasible. Among the challenges are (but not limited to): (i) a better understanding of the kinetics of HDO of model compounds and bio-oil; (ii) fundamental understanding of carbon formation mechanisms from various classes of compounds in pyrolysis oil composition, and (iii) defining the degree of oxygen removal in the context of further refining. A crucial step is to develop catalysts, with reduced costs and sufficiently high activity and high stability in hydroprocessing such aggressive and unstable pyrolysis liquids. Until today, classical sulfided hydrotreating catalysts [11–13], noble metals [11,12], phosphides [14–16], carbides [16,17], nitrides [16,17], non-precious metals [18–20], metal oxides [21,22], bimetallic amorphous boron-based catalysts [23,24] were studied in HDO of pyrolysis oils. Numerous studies have shown that the main reasons of catalysts deactivation are coke deposition onto the catalyst surface [5,25,26], poisoning by bio-oil impurities (S, N, K, Cl, etc.) [25,27], leaching of catalyst components [18,20], structural degradation in the presence of H2O [5,13,25], and sintering [15,23,24,28]. Coking is attributed to the reversible deactivation, as it might be possible to reactivate the catalyst by oxidation of coke. Deactivation associated with poisoning, leaching and sintering usually appears as irreversible and presents the main causes of the catalyst’s replacement. A robust catalyst that withstands the impact of aggressive feed and can be regenerated easily without losing too much activity is highly desired in the treating of pyrolysis liquids, hence allowing application on an industrial scale. Among the promising catalytic systems for such bio-liquids HDO the non-sulphided nickel-based catalysts have been accentuated, being monometallic [29–31], bimetallic Ni-Cu [32,33] and Ni-Mo catalysts [34]. The attractiveness of the nickel-containing systems is due to their high activity in hydrogenation reactions and the lower cost compared to hydrogenation catalysts based on precious metals [20,28,35]. An important advantage of the bimetallic Ni-Cu catalytic systems is their high reducibility under hydrotreatment process conditions and low activity towards undesirable methanation [36]. However, typical reasons for Ni based catalyst deactivation include above-mentioned sintering, coking, and leaching [18,20]. Ni-Mo systems indeed show increased corrosion stability in non-oxidizing solutions of mineral acids, such as hydrochloric, phosphoric, hydrofluoric acid, and dilute sulfuric acid with no oxygen dissolved [37,38]. Thus, the alloying of nickel with molybdenum improves corrosion resistance of Ni in such media approximately in proportion to the added molybdenum. For example, Ni-Mo alloys with 25–30 wt.% molybdenum are among the materials that are resistant to nonaerated hydrochloric acid at all concentrations and temperatures [37]. This is especially important for pyrolysis liquids hydrotreatment, since such liquids contain a large amount of organic acids (range from 5 to 12 wt.%) [8,39], and the process is carried out in a reducing atmosphere (H2). The aim of the present work is to specifically address the deactivation of Ni-based catalysts during HDO of pyrolysis liquids due to the leaching in the presence of an acid component. In a previous study the positive effect from both copper and molybdenum on the stability of tri-metalliс catalytic system NiCuMo-SiO2 was already noted [40], however, it was also shown that the treatment of these catalysts in acetic acid led to the sample mass loss. Here we provide a detailed investigation of the transformations taking place in the catalyst during the acidic treatment and subsequent reductive activation. A sol-gel prepared NiCuMo-SiO2 catalysts were treated with 1 M acetic acid for various times (15–360 min), while acetic acid is one of the main carboxylic acids in the bio-liquid [39,41]. To perform an ‘accelerated’ deactivation of the catalyst, the treatment by acid was carried out under oxidizing conditions, allowing air in the treatment system. The treated samples were studied by N2 physisorption, CO chemisorption, X-ray fluorescence (XRF), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and high resolution transition electron microscopy (HRTEM). Additionally, the subsequent reduction of the acid-treated catalysts was examined using in situ XRD and XPS techniques. The activity of the catalyst, both before and after this treatment was studied in HDO of propanoic acid being one acid model compound for the ‘carbohydrate’ fraction of pyrolysis oil. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The specific catalyst NiCuMo-SiO2 (Ni 50 wt.%, Cu 5.7 wt.%, Mo 9 wt.%, Si 7.5 wt.% for the oxidized catalyst) was prepared using heterogeneous sol-gel method described elsewhere [42]. All chemicals were used without no additional purification. Summarizing, appropriate amounts of commercially available NiCO3·mNi(OH)2·nH2O (98+%, JSC Reakhim, Russia), CuCO3·mCu(OH)2 (98+%, JSC Reakhim, Russia), (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (99.9%, JSC Reakhim, Russia) were mixed with the required amount of aqueous ammonia solution (25% NH3, 99.9+%, JSC Reakhim, Russia) in a ball mill. The suspension was filtered, dried in air at 120 °C for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. The thus obtained nickel–copper–molybdenum mixed oxide system was crushed and sieved (fraction 2–5 mm). Here after the granules were impregnated by commercial ethyl silicate-32 (99.9%, JSC Reakhim, Russia) with 32 wt.% SiO2 as the silica precursor. The granules were initially dried at room temperature, subsequently at 120 °C for 12 h after which they were calcined at 500 °C for another 4 h. The catalyst preparation procedure used in this study was somewhat inverse to a common impregnation method when solid catalyst support is impregnated by a metal salt solution. In the case of heterophase sol-gel synthesis the metallic precursor is in a solid state, when it is impregnated by ethyl silicate. Ethyl silicate is hydrolyzed followed by drying the gel coating of the metal precursor, which results in the formation of amorphous silica and silicate-alike species (silicate-silica net) on its surface at the final calcination stage [42]. The resulting silicon content in the catalyst NiCuMo-SiO2 was about 7.5 wt.%, and its function was to stabilize the active metallic phase during reduction and thermal treatments. In the final preparation stage the catalyst was reduced in a flow of H2 (1000 ml/min, 5.0 grade, Ltd Pure Gases, Russia) for 1 h at 500 °C in a quartz reactor with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The reduction temperature was chosen according to previous studies of Mo-modified systems based on TPR investigation of the catalyst (vide infra) [40]. After 1 h of the reductive treatment in a quartz reactor the catalyst was cooled down in a nitrogen flow. Upon reaching room temperature gas was switched to 0.5 vol.% O2/N2 (oxygen (4.6 grade), nitrogen (5.0 grade) from Ltd Pure Gases, Russia) at a flow rate of 0.8 l/min and the catalyst was passivated for 4 h. 2.2 Stability to corrosion The catalyst resistance to corrosion was determined by treatment with 1 M acetic acid water solution. Contact with ambient air oxygen was not specifically avoided during acidic treatment due to the intention of 'accelerated' catalyst deactivation under oxidizing conditions. For this, the as prepared catalyst was crushed and sieved to obtain a 250–500 μm fraction. Exact 1 g of catalyst was placed into the flask of 250 ml volume filled with 50 ml of 1 M acetic acid (99.9%, CJSC Base No.1 of chemical reagents, Russia) solution in distilled water, and left standing for a specific time (15, 30, 60, 180, or 360 min) at 100 °C, subsequently washed using distilled water and ethanol, dried at 100 °C overnight and weighed. The amount of acetic acid was fivefold (in moles) with respect to the metal content in the catalyst. The catalyst corrosion resistance was calculated from the sample mass loss (g) with respect to the initial value. All samples were collected for further characterization and activity testing and were denoted as NiCuMo-SiO2-15 m, NiCuMo-SiO2-30 m, NiCuMo-SiO2-60 m, NiCuMo-SiO2-180 m, NiCuMo-SiO2-360 m with respect to acidic medium exposure. 2.3 Catalyst characterization 2.3.1 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) Catalyst sample in oxidized state (0.1 g) was placed in a U-tube quartz reactor and treated in a reducing atmosphere (10 vol.% of H2 balanced in Ar at a flow rate of 20 ml/min) with a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 900 °C. The hydrogen concentration in the outlet stream during the reduction was measured with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3.2 X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF) Elemental composition of samples was determined using X-Ray fluorescence spectrometer ARL Advant’X 2247 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with Rh anode as an X-ray source. Mass percentage of elements was estimated using QuantAS software. 2.3.3 N2 physical adsorption Texture characteristics of samples were measured at the liquid nitrogen temperature using an ASAP-2400 automated volumetric adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics Instrument. Corp., USA). Before the analysis, the samples were de-gassed at 150 °C and pressure 0.13 Pa for 4 h. The analysis time was varied depending on the particular sample. The resulting adsorption isotherms were used to calculate the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller specific surface area (ABET), the total pore volume VΣ (from ultimate adsorption at a relative pressure of P/P0 = 1), the micropore volume Vμ, and the mean pore size. 2.3.4 CO chemisorption The amount of active surface sites of samples was determined by CO pulse chemisorption measurements using a Chemosorb analyzer (Modern laboratory equipment, Russia). 50 mg of each catalyst sample was placed inside U-shape quartz reactor and was treated in a H2 flow (100 ml/min) upon heating up to 400 °C, heating rate 20 °C/min. The reactor was kept at the final temperature for 20 min and then purged by inert gas He followed by cooling down to room temperature. After it pulses of CO were fed to the reactor (100 μL) until the amount of CO in the outlet stopped changing according to thermal conductivity detector. Thereafter the amount of chemisorbed CO was estimated. 2.3.5 High resolution transition electron microscopy (HRTEM) Electron microscopy investigation was performed using JEM-2010 (JEOL Ltd., Japan) and JEM-2200FS (JEOL Ltd., Japan) electron microscopes operated at 200 kV to obtain micrographs. The scanning transmission electron microscopy with high angle annular dark field mode mode was employed together with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). The samples for the HRTEM study were prepared on a holey carbon film mounted on an aluminum grid. 2.3.6 X-ray diffraction (XRD) Phase composition of fresh and acid treated catalyst samples was studied on a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) using CuK α radiation λ = 1.5418 Å with a step 2Ө = 0.05° and accumulation time 3 s at each point. The diffractometer was equipped with a linear LynxEye (1D) detector. In situ measurements were carried out using high-temperature chamber XRK-900 (Anton Paar, Austria). Each catalyst sample was reduced under a flow of hydrogen (30 ml/min) by heating (12 °C/min) up to the desired temperature. 2.3.7 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS was applied for the chemical analysis of the catalyst surface. XPS studies were performed on a SPECS’s spectrometer (Germany) equipped with an X-ray source XR-50 M with a twin Al/Ag anode, an ellipsoidal crystal X-ray monochromator FOCUS-500, and a hemispherical electron energy analyzer PHOIBOS-150. The photoelectron spectrometer was also equipped with a high-pressure cell (1 l volume), which enabled heating of samples in gaseous mixtures at pressures up to 0.5 MPa. XPS spectra were obtained using monochromatic AlKα radiation (h = 1486.74 eV) and a fixed analyzer pass energy of 20 eV under ultrahigh vacuum conditions. The binding energy scale was calibrated by the internal standard method using the Si2p peak at 103.30 eV. Relative element concentrations were determined from the integral intensities of XPS peaks using the cross-sections according to Scofield [43]. For detailed analysis the spectra were deconvoluted onto several peaks after the background subtraction by the Shirley method [44]. The deconvolution was performed using the CasaXPS software [45]. The line shapes were approximated by a convolution of Gaussian and Lorentz functions. Two types of catalysts were studied – samples after the acidic treatment and those after the following reduction in hydrogen. For the reduction the catalyst samples were treated directly in the high-pressure cell of the spectrometer at a hydrogen pressure of 0.1 MPa at 430 °C for 1 h. Thereafter, the catalysts were cooled down to the room temperature, evacuated and transferred to the analysis chamber without a contact with air. 2.4 Activity and stability in propionic acid HDO The activity of the catalysts in propionic acid (PA) hydrodeoxygenation reaction was investigated in fixed-bed plug flow reactors as comprised within the high-throughput kinetic mechanistic investigation setup (HTK-MI) at Ghent University [46,47]. Two of the eight parallel stainless steel tubular reactors, each 0.811 m in length and 0.011 m internal diameter, were employed for this purpose. The reactor tubes used in the experimentation with propionic acid are made of AISI 316 cold worked steel, which due to Mo content is showing an excellent resistance to corrosive materials. The temperature is measured and controlled with 3-point thermocouples allowing to measure the temperature at 3 different axial points inside the reactor. The total pressure within the reaction section of the set-up is maintained via a back-pressure regulator. Exactly 0.5 g of catalyst powder was pressed into flakes, crushed and sieved in order to obtain granules with a diameter of 400-600 μm. This ensured plug flow reactor behavior without excessive pressure drop. The catalyst granules were diluted with an equal amount of inert particles of α-Al2O3 of the same size, and then placed in the isothermal area of the reactor tube, between two layers of the same inert material. Thus, α-Al2O3 served as a physical support at the bottom of the reactor tube and was used to enhance evaporation and provide preheating of the inlet mixture at the top. In order to confirm the inert character of the α-Al2O3 particles as well as stainless steel material of reactor tubes during the reaction, blank experiment (no catalyst loaded) was performed prior to the tests. It was verified that no conversion of inlet components occurred even at the most severe operating conditions. After being loaded into the reactor tube, the catalyst was dried in a N2 atmosphere and reduced at 500 °C with 20 vol.% H2 in N2. 99.9% nitrogen and hydrogen were obtained from Air Liquide. Propionic acid (99%, Alfa Aesar) was fed to the reactor admixed with n-hexane (95+%, Acros Organics) as a diluent and n-octane (99+%, Acros Organics) as the internal standard. A mixture of hydrogen and nitrogen was introduced to the reactor in order to increase the dilution and avoid condensation of the reactor effluent in the analytical section. Liquid and gas feed were mixed right before the entrance to the reactor operated in the down flow regime. The activity of the catalyst samples (both the fresh and acetic acid treated ones) was measured at the following operating conditions: PA inlet partial pressure – 6.5·10−3 MPa, space time – 31 kgcat·s/molPA, H2/PA molar ratio – 38 molH2/molPA, total pressure – 0.5 MPa. The range of operating conditions chosen ensured that both reactants and reaction products remain in the gas phase, which allows one to avoid any impact of the vapor-liquid phase transfer phenomena on the observed chemical transformation and significantly simplifies data acquisition process. The activity tests were carried out at 225 °C after reaching the steady state of the catalyst. The reactor effluent was analyzed via an Agilent Technologies 6850 series II network gaseous chromatograph equipped with a PONA column and flame ionization detector. The outlet molar flow rates were determined using calibration factors that were obtained experimentally or reported by Dietz [48]. As the carbon and the mass balance were closed within ±5%, the normalization method was applied and the calculated values for the outlet flow rates were used to perform further data assessment [47]. In order to be able to focus solely on catalyst activity, it is important to separate catalyst activity from other interfering phenomena such as mass and heat transfer limitations and catalyst deactivation. In the experimental work performed the catalyst stability throughout the test was assessed by performing a reference experiment at regular time intervals. The catalyst loading was replaced after catalyst activity measured at reference conditions dropped by 5 mol. % compared to the one measured on the fresh catalyst. The conversion of propionic acid is defined via its inlet (FPA,0) and outlet molar flow rate (FPA): (1) X P A = F P A , 0 - F P A F P A , 0 The selectivity of propionic acid towards product i, Si, is calculated on a carbon basis from the molar flow rates of the reactant (FPA,0 and FPA) and product (Fi,0 and Fi): (2) S i = a i F i - F i , 0 3 F P A , 0 - F P A where ai is the number of carbon atoms in product i, Fi,0 and Fi – the molar inlet and outlet flowrate of the product i. It should be taken into account that the effective reduction of the catalyst bulk is needed in the case of either TPR and XRD studies, or the reductive activation of catalyst prior its treatment by HOAc and propionic acid HDO. Recently it was found that optimal and the most important conditions of the catalyst reduction include the heating rate not less than 10–15 °C, and the gaseous flow (pure hydrogen or H2 diluted with an inert gas) not less than 50 ml per 1 g of catalyst. Such conditions ensuring the effective reduction of the catalysts precursors as well as removal of released water were provided in the study. To reduce the catalyst surface species, as in the case of CO chemisorption and XPS study, less severe temperature conditions (about 400 °C) were sufficient for full reduction. In this respect, certain trends were observed in the corresponding experiments considered adequate for comparison. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst stability in model acidic solution The corrosion resistance was determined as the residual mass of the catalyst after the treatment. The results obtained are presented in Fig. 1 . An initial exponential decay in the residual mass is noted with time with the mass loss reaching a constant value after 180 min treatment. The fast initial mass loss is attributed to the dissolution of highly reactive species in the catalyst composition, with the more stable species remaining. It should be noted that the leaching of catalyst components consists of several processes, such as external diffusion, internal diffusion, and chemical reaction. In the present study, a simplified kinetic model was proposed with no detailed consideration of the diffusion aspects contribution into the overall leaching process. Since exponential decay in the catalyst mass was observed experimentally, the leaching model was based on a first-order reaction to describe the process. It was assumed that the mass of the reactive part of the sample, which is equal to the difference between the mass of the sample (m) and the mass of the residue after leaching (mresidue), varies according to the first-order reaction and follows the differential equation: (3) d m - m r e s i d u e d t = - k l e a c h · m - m r e s i d u e The solution of this equation is as follows: (4) m t , k l e a c h = m r e s i d u e + m 0 - m r e s i d u e · e - k l e a c h · t where m(t,kleach) − sample mass vs time (theoretic curve), mresidue − irreducible residue (g) (sample mass after 180 min), m0 – initial sample mass (g), kleach− effective rate constant of sample mass loss (min−1), t – leaching time. The effective rate constant kleach might depend on a number of parameters, such as temperature, porous structure and size of the catalyst grain, diffusion coefficients and mass transfer, and true reaction rate constant, which are not considered individually in the proposed model. The solution of the equation (3) with the normalization by the initial sample mass is provided in equation (5): (5) m t , k l e a c h m 0 = m r e s i d u e m 0 + 1 - m r e s i d u e m 0 · e - k l e a c h · t In the present study the initial sample mass m0 was 1 g, therefore normalized and absolute masses are the same in number. Minimization of function F given below by the least-squares method: (6) F = ∑ i m i - m ( t i , k l e a c h ) 2 Here ti is the time at point i, mi − measured sample mass (g) at time ti, to yield the value of an effective ‘rate constant of catalyst leaching’, kleach. Thus obtained theoretic curve is provided in Fig. 1 (dashed line). The effective rate constant kleach = 0.023 min−1 (at 100 °C) is obtained for NiCuMo-SiO2 catalyst as a characteristic of the leaching process under these specified conditions. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) The results of TPR investigation of fresh NiCuMo-SiO2 catalyst are provided in Fig. 2 . This H2-TPR reveal two temperature regions for the fresh catalyst: (i) A first region with a series of small peaks (150–350 °C) predominantly corresponding to the reduction of CuO, as well as to a well crystallized NiO with a defective structure and weakly interacting with SiO2; also Mo6+ reduction into Mо4+ can be observed in this region [40]. (ii) A high-temperature region with one dominant peak that correspond to the reduction of oxide-silicate Ni forms, Mo6+ species into Mo4+, and deeper reduction of Mo4+ into metallic Mо0 (Fig. 2) [32,40]. The presence of one intense hydrogen consumption peak on the TPR profile is explained by the formation of highly dispersed oxides of metals and their intimate contact [40,49]. Otherwise, several peaks could be expected on the TPR profile starting from 200 °C and corresponding to a separate reduction of Ni(II), Cu(II), and Mo oxide forms. It is also clear from Fig. 2 that the reduction of Moх+ species in this catalyst structure is easier due to activation of hydrogen molecules by a neighboring metallic nickel particles, as suggested by Brito et al. [49] during the reduction of bulk Ni-Mo oxides with atomic ratio Ni/(Ni + Mo)>0.55 (Ni/(Ni + Mo) = 0.9 for the present study). Based on the TPR profile of NiCuMo-SiO2 catalyst, a temperature 500 °C (the left ‘shoulder’ of dominant reduction peak) was chosen for reduction of the fresh catalyst. 3.2.2 X-ray fluorescence (XRF) It was assumed that the main weight loss in acid treatment was associated with metal leaching, as silica in the catalyst is reported to be stable under such conditions (stable in acidic medium, except hydrofluoric acid). Taking this into account, the metal to silicon M:Si ratio in the fresh catalyst and the M:Si ratios for the samples after acidic treatment was used to calculate the loss in metals. Fig. 3 shows that the most pronounced loss was observed for Ni (the ratio decreased approximately by a factor of two). The Mo:Si ratio decreased about 20%, while the Cu content remained rather stable with only a loss of approx. 6% of copper. Obviously, the main weight loss is the dissolution of nickel, also being the main constituent of the catalyst. Nickel is thus quite unstable in acidic medium, while copper and molybdenum are more resistant [37]. Apparently and in contrast to the sample mass (Fig. 1), the metals loss does not reach the plateau at 180 min. This can be explained by some oxidation of the catalyst, which is possible to take place either during acidic treatment or when the treated sample is dried in air. The oxidation leads to the increase in the total catalyst mass and compensates the mass loss by the metal leaching. Chemical transformations that may occur at these conditions are discussed in more detail below. 3.2.3 N2 physical adsorption and CO chemisorptions Fig. 4 presents time dependence of the specific surface area ABET for the reduced as prepared catalyst and acid treated samples. As it can be noticed, the specific surface area increases markedly from 199 m2/gcat for the fresh reduced catalyst to 334 m2/gcat after 360 min of acidic treatment. It is interesting to note that ABET curve resembles that of the catalyst residual mass (Fig. 1), with a rapid change in BET surface area up to 120 min of acidic treatment. At a longer treatment time the changes are less pronounced. A slight increase in the total pore volume VΣ was observed from 0.22 cm3/gcat for the fresh reduced catalyst NiCuMo-SiO2 to 0.28 cm3/gcat for NiCuMo-SiO2-360 m. The micropore volume Vμ was within 0.001 – 0.015 cm3/gcat and the mean pore size – from 3.2 nm to 4.4 nm, with no significant dependence on time of acidic treatment. The absolute amount of chemisorbed CO (μmol/g catalyst) is proposed to be a reliable parameter for comparison, as it appears complicated to properly define the active component surface for such catalytic systems. This is mainly caused by the different ways chemisorption of CO occurs on the various sites. For Ni the chemisorption is affected by the metal content, its interaction with the support, the metal particles dispersion, and the presence of impurities, and this results in several possible modes of adsorption such as linear, bridged and carbonyl type adsorption. These can occur simultaneously onto metallic surface [50,51]. Also different Mo sites can take part in CO adsorption according to [52]. Besides, the stoichiometry of adsorption is different, which further complicates the calculation of the specific surface area of active component. In the case of Cu the heat of adsorption of CO is very low if compared with Ni [51,53]. It is interesting to note that the CO uptake for the acid-treated samples (458–515 μmol/g) is higher than that for the fresh (reduced) catalyst (372 μmol/g) by analogy with total specific surface area ABET. However, as the time of acidic treatment of samples increases the amount of chemisorbed CO gradually goes down, which might be associated with dissolution of active metal in acidic medium. 3.2.4 High resolution transition electron microscopy (HRTEM) The metal leaching could indeed be confirmed by the HRTEM study. Fresh reduced catalyst is presented in Fig. 5 (a–c), and the sample after 360 min of acidic treatment in Fig. 5 (d–f). The micrographs of the fresh reduced sample show the presence of highly-dispersed uniformly distributed metallic particles with an average size of 6.8 nm. The EDX mapping (Fig. 6 ) obtained for the area presented in Fig. 5 (b) implies that all elements (Ni, Cu, Mo, Si) are uniformly distributed through the catalyst. In the case of the acid-treated sample metal-containing nanoparticles were hardly visible in the micrographs recorded in the bright field (Fig. 5 (d)). These images mainly show the presence of silicate-alike lamellar structures typical of sol-gel Ni-based catalytic systems [32]. The dark field regime revealed the presence of particles of metal oxides incorporated into the silica matrix (average size of oxidized particles 5.3 nm) (Fig. 5 (e)). The catalyst morphology changes markedly after acidic treatment (Fig. 5): the particles become smaller, the distance between the particles increases. This gives an additional evidence of the partial leaching of the catalyst components during the acidic treatment, which leads to the increasing catalyst surface revealed by N2 physical adsorption and CO uptake discussed above. It should be taken into account that dispersed systems such as catalysts are more prone to corrosion in comparison to bulk metals due to their defective structure. According to Semenova et al. [38], nickel and its alloys are prone to intergranular corrosion with the reaction taking place on the grain boundaries, which results in the formation of more fine particles. Moreover, the HRTEM data confirm the formation of highly dispersed oxidized particles after acidic treatment of the reduced catalyst. 3.2.5 X-ray diffraction (XRD) In order to understand phase changes taking place after acidic treatment all catalyst samples were studied using XRD (Fig. 7 ). The diffraction pattern of as prepared catalyst in the oxidized form reveals reflections corresponding to CuO and NiO phases. The shapes and intensities of these reflections are typical of similar catalysts [28,32,40]. After reduction and passivation the XRD pattern of the catalyst changes markedly (Fig. 7, red). It does not reveal reflections related to CuO phase, but trace amounts of NiO can be still observed (galo at 2θ = 30-40° and 60-66°). Ni and Cu are mainly in the reduced metallic state confirmed by the corresponding reflections on the diffraction pattern. Besides it should be noted that the position of peaks related to metallic Ni differs from the reference data [54], thus indicating the formation of Ni-based solid solutions with possible incorporation of Cu and/or Mo atoms into the metallic Ni structure [28,32,40]. When the reduced and passivated catalyst is treated by acidic solution, the diffraction pattern shows some transformations taking place with the catalyst. With increasing the treatment time, the relative intensity of metallic Ni reflections decreases until it complete disappears after approx. 360 min. At that time, the intensity of peaks corresponding to the NiO phase oppositely increases and their positions shift towards lower diffraction angles [55]. In particular, there is a shift of 220 reflection from 2θ = 62.2° to 60.2°. Moreover the relative intensity of NiO reflections changes if compared with the reference data [55] and it is more pronounced in the case of the sample treated for 360 min. A very likely reason is the formation of Ni(OH)2-alike structure, also confirmed by the XPS study discussed below. Additional sharp peaks appear in the XRD patterns at 2θ = 29.5, 36.5, 42.4, and 61.4° already after 15 min of the acidic treatment, and their intensity rises with time. These reflections were attributed to Cu2O phase [56], which could be formed in the presence of oxygen dissolved in acidic solution. Similarly to metallic Ni it is proposed that metallic Cu is re-oxidized and copper (I) oxide is formed. No reflections corresponding to Mo-containing phases are observed for all catalysts, which can be explained by a high dispersion of Mo species in the catalyst structure. Metallic species in the catalyst might also undergo oxidation by oxygen when the catalyst is dried in air after acidic treatment. In this case lots of defects being formed during acidic exposure of the metallic phase facilitate the oxidation process. Thus, the catalyst after the longest treatment (360 min) was in the most oxidized state with the most pronounced phase changes. The sample NiCuMo-SiO2-360 m treated for 360 min was studied using in situ XRD. The catalyst was reduced in situ in the diffractometer chamber at different temperatures, and XRD patterns were recorded. The results are presented in Fig. 8 (narrow 2θ range) and Fig. 9 (broad 2θ range). There are four narrow peaks on the diffraction pattern recorded for non-reduced sample at 25 °C (Fig. 8), which correspond to Cu2O phase (36.5 and 42.4°) and metallic Cu phase (43.3 and 50.5°). After the reductive treatment at 150 °C no considerable changes are observed in the diffraction pattern. At 200 °C the peaks corresponding to Cu2O phase disappear, while intensity of reflections of metallic Cu increases. This implies that copper (I) is reduced back into metallic Cu already at 200 °C, while Ni-containing phase remains unchanged. The XRD pattern recorded after in situ reduction at 300 °C is the same as at 200 °C. When the reduction temperature reaches 430 °C the diffraction pattern changes noticeably (Fig. 9). The intensity of broadened reflection at 32-40° changes and it slightly shifts towards higher diffraction angles more typical of NiO structure. This might result from the formation of a better crystallized NiO. Moreover the reflections appear at 43, 51 and 75° due to the formation of metallic Ni-riched (Ni*) solid solutions. These observations very likely point out that the reduction of Ni(OH)2-alike structure starts at approximatelly 400 °C resulting in the formation of active metallic Ni species. After the reduction at 500 °C the NiO reflections almost disappear indicating only trace amounts of NiO phase in the catalyst. Furthermore, the relative intensity of Ni* reflections continues to increase. It should be noted that even after the reductive treatment at 500 °C the Ni* reflections remain quite broad, indicating high dispersion of those species. No reflections corresponding to Mo-containing phases are observed in the diffraction patterns for all the temperatures concerned. This fact can be explained by both high dispersion of Mo-containing species and the incorporation of Mo atoms into the metallic Ni structure [40]. Thus, the in situ XRD study has shown that after the acidic treatment the catalyst is in an oxidized form, but it can be easily activated again by the reduction at 500 °C, which was to be done prior to kinetic measurements. 3.2.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The XPS spectra revealed the presence of peaks corresponding to Ni, Cu, Mo, Si, and O. Table 1 presents [Ni]:[Si], [Cu]:[Si] and [Mo]:[Si] atomic ratios on the samples surface. The first line in Table 1 corresponds to fresh reduced and passivated catalyst NiCuMo-SiO2, and its surface contains both Ni0 and Ni2+ species, copper being in the Cu0(1+) state. From the second column in Table 1 it is clear that the [Ni]:[Si] atomic ratios increase due to the acidic treatment, suggesting the appearance of additional Ni centers on the catalyst surface. Both the [Cu]:[Si] and [Mo]:[Si] ratios increase as well. It should be taken into account that [Cu]:[Si] ratio in the fresh catalyst is lower than [Mo]:[Si] ratio by one order of magnitude, though the atomic concentrations of Cu and Mo in the catalyst bulk should be quite close (Section 2.1). This observation might be explained by better reducibility of copper giving more pronounced agglomeration in comparison to Mo-containing species [57]. After a reductive treatment (Table 1) the [Ni]:[Si] ratio decreases for all samples (from 1 to nearly 0.4), and this is due to possible agglomeration of nickel particles. No noticeable difference in [Ni]:[Si] ratio is observed between the fresh reduced catalyst and acid treated-reduced samples (Table 1). The [Cu]:[Ni] ratio for these series increases, which is attributed to the localization of Cu in the near-surface layer of metallic Ni particles. Interestingly, after in situ reduction of samples by hydrogen the oxidized Mo species were only partially reduced into the metallic state (Table 1, column Mo0). The amount of Mo0 on the catalyst surface after the reduction increases with time of acidic treatment, and a very likely explanation is that the transformations taking place in the catalyst during acidic treatment advantageously affecting the reducibility of the Mo-species, improving the H2 availability to oxidized Mo species in a subsequent reduction. Fig. 10 presents the Si2p, Cu2p3/2 , Ni2p, and Mo3d core-level spectra of fresh, acid-treated, and in situ reduced NiCuMo-SiO2 samples. The Si2p binding energy for NiCuMo-SiO2 series is 103.3 eV, which corresponds to silicon in the Si4+ state. Since the Si2p binding energies given in the literature for SiO2 (103.3–103.8 eV [58]) and nickel silicates (103.0–103.5 eV [59]) are quite close, the present XPS data cannot give clear understanding of exact Si species presented in analyzed samples. Core-shell Ni2p spectra of acid-treated samples reveal Ni2+ oxidation state (Fig. 10, on the left). It is confirmed by two sharp peaks corresponding to the main doublet of Ni2p3/2 and Ni2p1/2 at 856.0–856.2 and 873.6–873.8 eV along with intense shake-up satellites. The presence of shake-up satellites is ascribed to a multiple electron excitation which is typical of Ni2+ species. For example, the intense shake-up satellites are observed in the XPS spectra of NiO, Ni(OH)2, NiSiO3, etc. [59–64]. In contrast to it, there are no shake-up satellites in the spectra of metallic nickel and Ni3+ species [60]. Moreover, the spin-orbit splitting equal to 17.6–17.8 eV is typical of oxidized nickel. Based on the literature data for Ni2+ this parameter is in the range 17.6–17.8 eV, while for metallic Ni it is about 17.3 eV [62,63]. It should be also noted that the shape of Ni2p spectra of acid treated samples is typical of Ni(OH)2, which have Ni2p3/2 binding energy in the range of 855.5–855.9 eV [62,64]. This effect might result from possible capture of H2O by surface NiO and the formation of Ni(OH)2 in the near-surface layer. The Ni2p spectra of in situ reduced samples (Fig. 10, on the right) reveal two sharp intensive peaks at 852.7 and 869.9 eV corresponding to the doublet Ni2p3/2 and Ni2p1/2 of Ni in the metallic state, while the additional low intensity peaks at 858.6 and 874.7 eV are due to plasmon excitation. These data point out the formation of metallic nickel species in the surface layer of catalysts after reductive treatment [63]. The spin-orbit splitting of 17.2 eV is an additional evidence for this conclusion. The detailed analysis of Cu2p3/2 core-level spectra of acid-treated non-reduced samples was hampered due to low signal-to-noise ratio (spectra are not shown). Nonetheless, it was noted that a part of copper was in a reduced state (Cu1+ or Cu0). As for in situ reduced samples the Cu2p3/2 core-shell spectra reveal a symmetric narrow peak at 932.3 eV. The presence of Cu2+ species was excluded because of the absence of lines at higher binding energies as well as shake-up satellites typical of these species [64–66]. The peak at 932.3 eV might be attributed to Cu0 or Cu1+ species. To distinguish these two forms the Auger-parameter is typically used, however in the present study the estimation of this parameter is complicated due to a very low copper concentration. Nevertheless, in our previous studies full reduction of copper into metallic Cu0 was observed after such reductive treatment [32]. Furthermore, the presence of fully reduced Ni in these samples provides an additional evidence of Cu being in the metallic state, as Cu is characterized by higher reduction ability if compared with Ni. The Mo3d spectra (Fig. 10, on the left) reveal intensive doublet Mo3d5/2 -Mo3d3/2 with Mo3d5/2 binding energy of 232.9 eV corresponding to Mo6+ species. Moreover, in the case of NiCuMo-SiO2, NiCuMo-SiO2-15 m, NiCuMo-SiO2-30 m and NiCuMo-SiO2-60 m samples additional low-intensity doublet with Mo3d 5/2 line at 231.1 eV is observed. This value corresponds to molydbenum in Mo5+ state. According to the literature data, the Mo3d5/2 binding energies of Mo0, Mo4+, Mo5+ and Mo6+ species correspond to 227.7–227.9, 229.2–229.9, 230.8–231.6 and 232.7–233.2 eV, respectively [67–71]. After in situ reduction of acid-treated samples (Fig. 10, on the right) oxidized molybdenum species undergo partial reduction. The percentage of each Mo form related to the total molybdenum amount was estimated from XP-spectra (Table 1). The data obtained indicates that molybdenum was reduced mainly into intermediate Mo4+ state in contrast to Ni and Cu. Overall, there is no clear dependence of relative concentration of different Mo species on the time of acidic treatment based on XPS data. 3.3 Chemical transformations of catalyst exposed to 1 M acetic acid This section concerns more substantively the chemical transformations of the metallic species in NiCuMo-SiO2 catalyst during its treatment by 1 M acetic acid solution. In order to address these transformations the results of physico-chemical characterization provided above (Section 3.2) are to be taken into account. Remarkably, the color of the catalysts changes with the increase of the acid treatment time (see also Fig. 11 ). Where the freshly reduced-passivated sample (Fig. 11, 0 min) is deeply-black, the longest acidic treatment causes the color to become almost colorless with slight green and yellow tints (360 min). This is a result from the progressive oxidation of metals in the catalyst structure (reduced nickel is black, whereas nickel oxide is green, while molybdenum (VI) oxide is yellow). Catalyst oxidation was confirmed via XRD, showing the formation of NiO and Cu2O phases. The XPS analysis confirmed changes in the surface composition after acidic treatment – the percentage of Mo6+ increases with exposure duration. During acidic treatment metals undergo partial dissolution, while remaining species are oxidized by air oxygen dissolved in acidic solution or after that when drying. The interesting fact is that according to the XRD measurements the catalyst undergoes gradual oxidation originating from continuous degradation of catalyst structure, such as defects formation. The longer the treatment is, the more pronounced the changes are, so longest treated catalyst is more oxidized. The presence of oxygen facilitates corrosion process [37], whereas reducing conditions might prevent it. Moreover, nickel has notable corrosion resistance to most nonaerated organic acids and other organic compounds, so its alloys are likewise used in the production of acetic acid as the materials for the downstream process equipment [37,72,73]. In the present study the oxidizing conditions by the presence of oxygen in air (and in the water) resulted in more severe conditions to study the catalyst corrosion resistance compared with the real pyrolysis oil hydrotreatment conditions, providing an ‘accelerated deactivation’ of the catalyst. Under these acidic treatment conditions nickel is subjected to oxidation in the presence of air with the subsequent formation of water soluble nickel acetate as one of possible routes leading to nickel leaching (equation 7 hereunder). Nickel acetate is also formed from the reaction between acetiс acid and the NiO oxide remaining from reduction (8), and reaction of metallic nickel with acetic acid associated with the release of hydrogen (9). The stability of nickel species that are in more intimate contact with molybdenum and copper is supposedly higher, but these nickel species also can undergo oxidation in the presence of air O2 when drying the samples. (7) Ni + 2HOAc + 1/2O2 → Ni(OAc)2 + H2O (8) NiO + 2HOAc → Ni(OAc)2 + H2O (9) Ni + 2HOAc → Ni(OAc)2 + H2 Copper is corrosion-resistant in dilute, nonoxidizing, nonaerated solutions of mineral acids and also of most of organic acids, for example, acetic or formic acid, even at quite high temperatures. It might be only attacked by hot concentrated solutions of these acids [37]. In the presence of air oxygen copper is more stable as compared to nickel [38]. For comparison, the electrochemical potential (φ°, V) of Ni is negative, and equal to -0.234 V, while copper has a positive potential +0.522 V and, hence, it is less prone to oxidation. When nickel and nickel alloys are alloyed with copper, their resistance to nonoxidizing acid solutions are generally improved [37]. Nevertheless, in the present study Cu2O was observed after acid treatment, and its amount increased with time of treatment. Thus, it is possible that the metallic copper in the fresh reduced catalyst was subjected to oxidation by air O2 dissolved in the acid solution with the formation of water insoluble solid Cu(I) oxide (10). The Cu2O oxide is expected to react with acetic acid with the formation of water soluble Cu(I) acetate (11), which in turn is subjected to further oxidation by O2 into Cu2+ in the solution (12). However, these transformations result in a very little copper leaching, which was confirmed by XRF analysis. (10) 2Cu + 1/2O2 → Cu2O (11) Cu2O + 2HOAc → 2CuOAc + H2O (12) 2CuOAc + 1/2O2 + 2HOAc → 2Cu(OAc)2 + H2O Molybdenum exhibits a very good corrosion resistance to nonoxidizing solutions of hydrochloric, phosphoric, and hydrofluoric acid at most concentrations and temperatures, it is also stable in a boiling sulfuric acid up to a concentration of 60% [37]. The alloys of nickel with molybdenum show higher corrosion resistance, as for example nickel-molybdenum alloys containing 26–30 wt.% of Mo are even resistant to airless hydrochloric acid. In the present study the formation of molybdenum blues of two Mo oxidized states 5+ and 6+ might take place (13). This assumption was confirmed by the color of acidic solution, which became bluish with time. These molybdenum blues might be precipitated back to the catalyst surface during the treatment and lead to the formation of more fine particles. (13) Mo2O5 + 3MoO3 → Mo5O14*nH2O 3.4 Catalyst activity in propionic acid HDO The effect of acidic pre-treatment on the catalyst performance was evaluated by hydrogenating propionic acid as a model component for fast-pyrolysis liquids. The reaction product spectrum comprised mainly propanol, methane, ethane, propane, propionaldehyde and propyl propanoate. Additionally, a trace amount of diethyl keton was detected. Carbon selectivities towards each of these reaction product are listed in Table 2 . Based on the observed experimental results, the reaction scheme for propionic acid hydrogenation over NiCuMo-SiO2 was proposed in agreement with our recent study [74], see Fig. 12 . The major reaction pathway for propionic acid is through hydrogenolysis of the C–O bond, to yield propionaldehyde with water as a by-product (see Fig. 12) [75–77], followed by further hydrogenation of almost all of this propionaldehyde to propanol, which is the majorly observed reaction product. Propane can be formed via the dehydration of propanol to propene with further hydrogenation to propane in a hydrogen-rich environment. Apart from this, propanol can be partially converted to propyl propanoate via an esterification reaction with propionic acid [78]. Another possible pathway leads to ethane by decarbonylation and decarboxylation routes [79–81]. In case of decarbonylation, carbon monoxide and water are formed as by-products, and for decarboxylation carbon dioxide (Fig. 12). Analysis of the reactor effluent with a gaseous chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector only showed traces of carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide. Together with the presence of methane in the reactor effluent, this observation proposes methanation of the formed carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide, which is supported by the evidence for the high activity of nickel in methanation reactions [82,83]. Additionally, NiCuMo-SiO2 catalyst was observed to exhibit low ketonisation activity (Fig. 12), which results in diethyl keton formation [76,84]. Fig. 13 depicts the propionic acid conversion at constant reaction time and conditions with the increase in time of a prior catalyst treatment by 1 M HOAc. The propionic acid conversion is 28 mol.% for the fresh catalyst, but rapidly decreases with the catalyst acidic pre-treatment time until it reaches a value of 12–15 mol.% for the catalysts exposed to the acidic medium for longer than 180 min. Notably, the propionic acid conversion curve in Fig. 13 resembles the change in nickel content in the catalyst (Fig. 3), and therefore, the rapid drop of the catalyst activity is likely associated with the decreasing amount of active component. These results pointed out that the increased active component surface after pre-treatment in acetic acid (see Fig. 4) did not result in higher activity of the catalyst. The amount of active sites probably decreases under the hydrotreatment conditions and active component content became the determining factor of the catalyst activity. It is assumed that after treatment by HOAc those dispersed active metal particles with an extended surface are very likely subjected to agglomeration during HDO of propionic acid. Previously it was shown [85] that similar catalysts are prone to deeper hydrogenation of oxidized species along with agglomeration of metallic phase during pyrolysis oil hydrotreatment. The reason could be simultaneously associated with the presence of organic matter and reductive atmosphere of hydrogen as inducing factors. There is no particularly pronounced dependence of selectivity towards the reaction products on the acetic acid pretreatment time (Table 2). All catalysts in the series demonstrate close selectivities towards the reaction products in the investigated operating conditions with the highest inclination of propionic acid conversion into propanol via hydrogenation route. These results provide understanding that preliminary acidic treatment of catalyst does not change the nature of active sites, but mainly causes propionic acid conversion by decreasing amount of active metal. 4 Conclusions There is large interest towards the development of stable and active catalysts for the hydrotreatment of biomass pyrolysis liquids, as these liquids may represent a cost-effective intermediate product to obtain 2nd Generation biofuels. Finding catalytic systems with sufficiently high activity, and more importantly, a high stability is one of the key challenges towards industrial feasibility of the process. The present work particularly focuses on an important issue related to deactivation of high-loaded Ni-based catalysts (NiCuMo-SiO2) by leaching of active components in the presence of organic acids in pyrolysis oils. An approach proposed in the study was based on treating the reduced NiCuMo-SiO2 catalyst in 1 M acetic acid, with a model pH of 2–3 close to that of the real pyrolysis oil. Besides, more severe conditions compared with the hydrotreatment of pyrolysis liquid were provided for ‘accelerated deactivation’ of the catalyst in the presence of oxygen (aerated acidic solution). At these conditions, the exponential loss of the catalyst mass was observed with a residual mass of catalyst reaching a plateau after prolonged acidic exposure. It should be taken into account that there might be a number of possible reasons accounting for the formation of this residue, which have either thermodynamic or kinetic origin. For deep understanding of the process, a big set of parameters is to be evaluated such as activity coefficients, standard potentials and their dependence on temperature, constantly changing structure of catalyst surface and composition, partial pressures of gaseous components and their solubility in the liquid solution, etc. This quite challenging and complex task is of particular importance and it will be considered in our forthcoming studies. In the present study, a simplified first-order kinetic model was proposed to provide a mathematical description of the catalyst mass loss. It is to be noted that primarily Ni was leached from the catalyst during acidic treatment through the formation of water soluble nickel acetates, which was induced by additional oxidation of metallic species in aerated acidic solution. The loss of Mo was much less pronounced, whereas as expected copper showed almost no dissolution. Besides, oxidation of the catalysts was demonstrated, taking place either during acidic treatment or by drying the samples under air. Indeed gradual re-oxidation of metallic forms in the catalyst was demonstrated: metallic Cu phase conversion into Cu2O, and Ni ‒ into NiO and Ni(OH)2-alike phases. The specific surface area increased gradually with time of acidic treatment in comparison to that of the fresh reduced catalyst. The amount of active metal sites was also increased after acidic exposure associated with the formation of more dispersed particles. This very likely is due to the intergranular corrosion of metallic Ni particles with the reaction taking place on the grain boundaries, which results in the formation of more fine particles. Nevertheless, the activity of the acid treated catalysts in the hydrodeoxygenation of propionic acid ‒ a very simplified model compound for pyrolysis liquid ‒ at 225 °C showed a gradual decrease if the acid treatment times are prolonged, associated with the loss of leached active components, mostly the Ni. The active surface area is very likely reduced under these hydrotreatment conditions due to agglomeration of metallic phase in the presence of organic matter and reductive atmosphere of hydrogen. Thus, active component content became the determining factor of the catalyst activity. According to the aforementioned results, the following main conclusions can be drawn: 1 High-loaded Ni-SiO2 catalyst modification by Mo and Cu results in the formation of metallic solid solutions with possible incorporation of Cu and/or Mo atoms into the metallic Ni structure. Despite this modification, the catalyst is subjected to dissolution in model acidic medium mainly due to the formation of water-soluble acetates. 2 The presence of modifying additives did not allow sufficient stabilization of Ni and its resistance in acidic medium pointing at the need for additional catalyst improvement. 3 The metals leaching is induced by additional oxidation of metallic species in the presence of oxygen in aerated acidic solution. 4 Overall, the proposed model acidic treatment might be positioned as a quite rough estimate for the catalyst leaching performance under real pyrolysis oil hydrotreatment conditions. This is due to actual complexity of the hydrotreatment process, when a number of factors simultaneously affect the catalyst, such as coking the catalyst surface, sintering of active phase, leaching of catalyst components, strong adsorption of intermediate compounds on the active sites causing deactivation, etc. 5 Nevertheless, the acidic treatment procedure proposed in the study for ‘accelerated deactivation’ of catalysts might be positioned as a good tool to compare the catalysts with respect to their leaching ability, which is essential for use in hydrotreatment of pyrolysis liquids. For this, it is needed to treat the catalysts at the same conditions in acidic solution such as duration, cat/acid ratio, etc. It is also important that the proposed kinetic model for the catalyst leaching considers transformations of its reactive part and thus non-reactive one is to be defined. coredata.dc:description: The main reasons of catalysts deactivation in hydro-processing pyrolysis liquids are by coke deposition, poisoning by bio-oil impurities (S, N, K, Cl, etc.), leaching of catalyst components, structural degradation in the presence of H2O, and sintering. The deactivation of catalysts by the acidity of the pyrolysis liquid is a specific concern, and this deactivation mechanism was studied by treating newly developed NiCuMo-SiO2 catalysts in 1 M acetic acid water solution (pH = 2–3). The activity of the acid-treated catalysts was subsequently investigated in the hydrodeoxygenation of gaseous propionic acid, in a tubular reactor at 225 °C with n-hexane and n-octane serving as diluent and internal standard, respectively. The samples treated by acid at different times (15–360 min) were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), high resolution transition electron microscopy (HRTEM), X-ray fluorescence (XRF), CO chemisorption, N2 physical adsorption, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). XRF and HRTEM studies together with the residual mass of catalyst pointed out at gradual leaching of catalyst components. Among the catalyst components, dissolution of nickel was the most pronounced, while molybdenum content decreased to a lesser extent. This is due to the formation of more acid stable molybdenum blues. The amount of copper decreased only slightly, due its higher electrochemical potential. Oxidation of metalliс species Cu and Ni is shown to obtain Cu2O, NiO and Ni(OH)2-like phases. Interestingly, the acidic treatment resulted in increasing active surface of the catalyst, nevertheless, the catalyst activity in propionic acid conversion irreversibly decreased in time by the acetic acid treatment due to loss of the active components (substantially nickel).
coredata.dc:title: NiCuMo-SiO2 catalyst for pyrolysis oil upgrading: Model acidic treatment study
